XML finding aid derived from HTML version through cutting and pasting and through folder analysis. 2013
Finding aid encoded by Tiffany Saulter, Lilly Library, Indiana University, November 12, 2013

did.head: Summary Information
did.unittitle: Whitman mss.
did.abstract: The Whitman mss., 1846-1878, consist of correspondence of Mrs. Sarah Helen (Power) Whitman, 1803-1878.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Whitman was born in Providence, Rhode Island and became a poet, transcendentalist, and Spiritualist. She was an admirer of Ralph Waldo Emerson and frequenter of the intellectual social circles of her era, like that of her friend Margaret Fuller. It was in this environment that Whitman met the poet and author Edgar Allan Poe, with whom she had a controversial love affair. Whitman and Poe were engaged to be married in 1848, but the relationship dissolved. Poe died not long after, in 1849. Whitman went on to publish a collection of poems, Hours of Life, in 1853, as well as a defense of Poe, Edgar Allan Poe and His Critics, in 1860. Nearly all of the correspondence in the collection concerns Whitman's relationship with Poe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include: Mrs. Anne Charlotte (Lynch) Botta, William Hand Browne, Joseph Rhodes Buchanan, Franklin Burdge, Mrs. Maria (Poe) Clemm, George William Curtis, James Wood Davidson, Eugene Lemoine Didier, George Washington Eveleth, James Thomas Fields, William Fearing Gill, Rufus Wilmot Griswold, Mrs. Mary Elizabeth (Moore) Hewitt, Marie L. Houghten, John Henry Ingram, Thomas Carstairs Latto, Edgar M. Levan, W. J. McClellan, John Neal, John Owen, Sara Sigourney Rice, Sarah Elizabeth Robins, Mrs. Elizabeth Oakes (Prince) Smith, Richard Henry Stoddard, John William Weidemeyer. Two letters of the collection, Mrs. Sarah Helen Whitman to John Neal, November 11, 1874, and Neal's reply, November 13, 1874, about L'Affaire "Musiad" have been published by David Randall in The J. K. Lilly Collection of Edgar A. Poe, Bloomington, Indiana, 1964, pages 49 and 50 (see: Lilly PS2628 .R187).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Poe mss., also located at the Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired from the library of Josiah Kirby Lilly, Jr., Indianapolis, Indiana.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Whitman mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
